MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Bovine TB Eradication.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: if he will give an annual breakdown of his Department's total expenditure on bovine TB eradication programmes for the five years from 1988 to 1992; if this disease is diminishing; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Details of expenditure by ERAD (The Eradication of Animal Disease Board) on bovine TB eradication/brucellosis eradication during the period 1988 to 1992 is as outlined beneath. It is not possible to segregate expenditure on these programmes because of shared costs.

MainHeading.P: A full round of TB testing was completed in 1992. Some 35,000 reactors were disclosed, and the APT (reactors per thousand tests) of 3.3 was less than the 1991 figure of 4.4. This out-turn indicates a slightly reduced disease incidence. However, it remains to be seen whether the downward trend will continue. The 1993 TB round is scheduled to commence at an early date.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: if he intends to extend the closing dates for the male beef premium scheme in 1993 as there is no restriction applying from Brussels on the number of beef premia applications in a member state.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: The EC regulations governing the special beef premium scheme allow member states to limit the number of applications which may be submitted by a producer in a year in order to facilitate administration of the scheme. My Department intends to have at least three application periods for the special beef premium scheme in 1993 compared with two application periods in 1992.

Later in the year, I will be reviewing our experience of implementing the Common Agricultural Policy reform measures and, in that context, I will examine the necessity for having greater flexibility in the implementation of the scheme.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: if he intends to allow Irish sheep farmers the benefit of two premia application periods as applies to the sheep farmers in the UK; if not, the reason therefor; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: In accordance with normal practice the application period here was set for early March. The date was subsequently extended to 19 March 1993 in order to give more time to farmers to submit their applications. Later in the year, I will be reviewing our experience of implementing the Common Agricultural Policy reform measures and in that context I would hope to be able to agree to an earlier application period in future years.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: if he intends to notify Irish sheep farmers of their individual sheep quotas; and, if so, when this information will be provided.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: EC regulations provide for ewe premium quota to be allocated to those flockowners who were paid the ewe premium in 1991 and who applied for the premium in 1992. These regulations also provide that flockowners who received no premium or a reduced premium in 1991 because of certain natural circumstances may be allocated a quota based on an earlier year when those natural circumstances did not obtain. Furthermore, flockowners who were paid a reduced premium or no premium because of the application of penalties may be allocated a quota based on the number of eligible ewes found at the inspection which led to those penalties.

These provisions require my Department to examine a substantial number of individual files in order to establish the precise entitlement of each flockowner to a quota. This exercise will be completed shortly and flockowners will be notified of their quota entitlement shortly thereafter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Wexford Land Disposal.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: the date on which the Land Commission received an application from a person (details supplied) for permission to sub-divide and the lifting of an inhibition on the sale of certain lands in County Wexford; the reason this permission was granted but no communication regarding the inhibition of sale was issued; the reason, if any, for refusing to lift the inhibition of sale; when this matter will be resolved; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: There are two separate issues involved here. One is the question of subdivision control which derives from Section 12 of the Land Act, 1965 and applies to all subdivisions. The other issue concerns the specific inhibition on the sale of certain lands without the consent of the Land Commission which dervies from the fact that part of the lands involved are the subject of a rearrangement scheme prepared by the Commission at the request of the landowner.
As details of individual application under Section 12 are not recorded I am not in a position to provide the information requested on the first issue.

On the issue of the inhibition on sale I can confirm that a request dated 29 January 1993 for consent to a transfer was received in the Land Commission on 2 February 1993. This request is being examined with a view to determining whether lands involved lie outside the scheme of rearrangement and thus whether consent can be given.
I would hope to have an early decision on this matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sheep Quota Application.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: if a decision has been made regarding an application for an extra sheep quota by a person (details supplied) in County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: The relevant EC Regulations provide for ewe premium quotas to be based on the number of ewes on which a producer was paid the ewe premium in 1991 provided that the producer also applies for the premium in 1992.

MainHeading.P: The persons named meet both of these conditions and will be granted a quota based on the number of ewes on which they were paid premium in 1991 less any deduction for the natural reserve. EC Regulations provide for the establishment of such a national reserve and also of a special reserve for the Disadvantaged Areas for allocation to certain categories of sheep producers. When the criteria for the allocation of these reserves to Irish sheep producers have been finalised it will be open to the persons named to submit an application to my Department along with supporting documentation, for an allocation of additional quota from the reserve quotas.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Job Sharing in the Health Services.

Qst.Quest: his views on job sharing in the health services; and the number of health service workers who are currently employed on a job-sharing basis.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: My Department's Health Services Personnel Census indicates that there were 3,248 persons employed at the end of December, 1991 in a job-sharing capacity in the health services. A measure of the success of the job-sharing scheme, which was introduced in 1985, is the fact that there were a thousand more persons employed in a job-sharing capacity at the end of 1991 than at the end of 1989.

MainHeading.P: Job sharing allows for flexibility in working arrangements for both employees and employers. The scheme, however, necessarily provides that the granting of job sharing arrangements is a matter for the employing health agency concerned and is subject to the exigencies of the service.

I am committed to encouraging health agencies to allow the scheme to be used to the fullest possible extent. In this regard, my Department is undertaking a review of the scheme with a view to seeing what further steps can be taken to expand it.

Qst.Quest: the incidence of TB among patients and staff in the psychiatric and mental handicap services; and if he will give details of screening and other preventative services available.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: There is a statutory requirement on all general practitioners to notify their local Director of Community Care/Medical Officer of Health (DCC/MOH) of all cases of tuberculosis. The DCC/MOHs in turn notify my Department of all cases reported to them as occurring in their area. No breakdown is given to my Department as to whether the cases being notified are in a psychiatric or mental handicap service. However in the event of a serious outbreak it would be normal for the DCC/MOH to communicate directly with the medical staff of my Department. The DCC/MOHs take whatever action they consider necessary in the interest of public health including contact tracing and prophylactic treatment.

My Department's policy in relation to tuberculosis is being examined by a working party under the chairmanship of the Chief Medical Officer of my Department. The group is examining all aspects of tuberculosis including notification, surveillance, treatment and contact tracing procedures. Their main aim will be to ensure that there is an appropriate framework to deal with all problems associated with tuberculosis.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Third Level Grant Regulations.

Qst.Quest: if the third-level grant regulations of 1992 will apply retrospectively; if all new entrants will be assessed under all the new regulations; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
